citations.narrative:
The facility is not providing adequate shelter for the dogs. The outdoor housing area that is currently housing 5 adult
golden retrievers has two large dome-shaped shelter structures that do not have a floor as required. The shelter
structures are sitting directly on top of compacted earth.
The shelter structures not having an adequate floor can prevent the dogs from remaining dry, clean, and warm which can
lead to discomfort and illness. The facility must ensure the shelter structures in outdoor facilities for dogs contain a roof,
four sides, and a floor.
Correct by 4 June 2025

Food receptacles are not being kept clean and sanitized. In two primary enclosures located in the outdoor housing area of
the facility housing 5 adult golden retrievers and 4 adult Bernese Mountain dogs the applicant is utilizing 3 metal gravity
feeders as the food receptacles for the dogs. The feeders were observed with an excessive buildup of thick brown food
residue caked onto the interior surfaces at the bottom of the feeders.
Food residue and organic material buildup can harbor microorganisms that can result in disease and health problems in
dogs. The applicant must ensure that food receptacles are kept cleaned and sanitized in accordance with 3.11(b).
Correct by 19 May 2025

Water receptacles are not being kept clean and sanitized. In the outdoor housing area, the applicant is using a large hard
rubber trough as the water receptacle that is shared between two primary enclosures housing 5 adult golden retrievers
and 4 adult Bernese Mountain dogs. The water receptacle was observed to have a green algae-like organic material
coating the bottom interior surface of the trough.
Algae buildup in the receptacle indicates cleaning is not occurring on a frequent enough basis and could cause the water
to become contaminated. Contaminated water is no longer considered to be safe to consume and could lead to potential
health risks. Clean water receptacles are important to promote good health for the animals and reduce the risk of disease.
The applicant must ensure all water receptacles be kept clean and sanitized in accordance with 3.11(b).
Correct by 19 May 2025
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 30 June 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.4(b) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The facility is not providing adequate shelter for the dogs. The outdoor housing area that is currently housing 5 adult 
golden retrievers has two large dome-shaped shelter structures that do not have a floor as required. The shelter 
structures are sitting directly on top of compacted earth.  
 
The shelter structures not having an adequate floor can prevent the dogs from remaining dry, clean, and warm which can 
lead to discomfort and illness. The facility must ensure the shelter structures in outdoor facilities for dogs contain a roof, 
four sides, and a floor.  
 
Correct by 4 June 2025 
3.9(b) 
   
Feeding 
Food receptacles are not being kept clean and sanitized. In two primary enclosures located in the outdoor housing area of 
the facility housing 5 adult golden retrievers and 4 adult Bernese Mountain dogs the applicant is utilizing 3 metal gravity 
feeders as the food receptacles for the dogs. The feeders were observed with an excessive buildup of thick brown food 
residue caked onto the interior surfaces at the bottom of the feeders.  
 
Food residue and organic material buildup can harbor microorganisms that can result in disease and health problems in 
dogs. The applicant must ensure that food receptacles are kept cleaned and sanitized in accordance with 3.11(b).  
 
Correct by 19 May 2025 
3.10(c) 
   
Watering 
Water receptacles are not being kept clean and sanitized. In the outdoor housing area, the applicant is using a large hard 
rubber trough as the water receptacle that is shared between two primary enclosures housing 5 adult golden retrievers 
and 4 adult Bernese Mountain dogs. The water receptacle was observed to have a green algae-like organic material 
coating the bottom interior surface of the trough.

Algae buildup in the receptacle indicates cleaning is not occurring on a frequent enough basis and could cause the water 
to become contaminated. Contaminated water is no longer considered to be safe to consume and could lead to potential 
health risks. Clean water receptacles are important to promote good health for the animals and reduce the risk of disease. 
The applicant must ensure all water receptacles be kept clean and sanitized in accordance with 3.11(b).  
 
Correct by 19 May 2025 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 30 June 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
